Dear Janice Black-Moore:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000716
Special Investigation Intake Date: May 21, 2025
License #: CB630201417
Licensee Group Organization: Spectrum Child & Family Services
Licensee Designee: Stacie Bowens
Chief Administrator: Janice Black-Moore
Agency Name: SPECTRUM HUMAN SERVICES
Agency Address: 16250 NORTHLAND DR
SOUTHFIELD, MI 48075-5205
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 07/07/2027
II. METHODOLOGY

1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
Section • (2) Initial consideration must be given to placement with a
Description relative or placing siblings together, or both.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are concerns that relative placements were not explored.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Parent A was interviewed by phone on 5/23/2025. Parent A
expressed concern regarding her daughter’s current placement
and agency staff’s failure to place Youth A with a relative. Parent
A’s statements were, at times, disjointed and attempts to seek
clarification were unsuccessful. She stated Youth A accused
Parent A of physically abusing her after which Youth A ran away.
When Youth A was located, MDHHS placed Youth A with her
father. Youth A kept running away from her father’s home to
Caregiver A’s home, during that time. Parent A stated MDHHS
removed Youth A from her father’s care at which time she was
placed with Caregiver A. She stated Caregiver A is an unlicensed
foster parent who they are referring to as fictive kin; however,
Parent A does not know the family. She initially stated Youth A
was having sex with Caregiver A’s brother, then later stated she
did not know how Youth A knows Caregiver A. At a different point
in the interview, she stated Caregiver A is Youth A’s boyfriend’s
sister, but later stated Youth A did not have a boyfriend as she
was not allowed to “do anything out of the will of God,” and Youth
A could not spend time with anyone Parent A had not met. Parent
A also stated Caregiver A lived in the same apartment complex as
Parent A and Youth A, but they did not know one another.
Parent A reported Youth A has adult siblings with whom she could
live, but the agency has not pursued those options. Parent A
stated Sibling 1, who lives in Texas, expressed interest in
placement of Youth A so the Judge ordered that Interstate
Compact on the Placement of Children (ICPC) become involved.
Parent A reported the agency staff lied and said Sibling 1 became
homeless, so ICPC closed the case. Parent A stated the agency
contacted Sibling 2 for placement of Youth A , but Youth A said
she didn’t want to go to any of her siblings’ homes. Parent A
stated she believed Youth A thinks her siblings are mad because
Parent A went to jail and has a criminal case pending for allegedly
abusing Youth A, which Parent A denies doing. Parent A stated
Sibling 3 was living with Parent A and has an MDHHS case open,
so she wasn’t a placement option and Sibling 4 is in jail. She did
2

not mention any other siblings. During this interview, Parent A
stated multiple times that Youth A talks with her siblings and has
told them she wants to stay with Caregiver A and does not want to
live with her siblings or Parent A. Parent A ended the placement
discussion by stating the agency staff have never searched for a
family placement.
Program Manager was interviewed via video conferencing on
5/30/2025. She reported not working for the agency when the
case first came into care, but she knows agency staff made efforts
through ICPC to locate relative placement with Sibling 1 in Texas;
however, Sibling 1 became homeless so Youth A could not be
placed with her. Program Manager did not know any details about
the other siblings, but remembered none of them were appropriate
for placement. Program Manager stated Youth A is placed with
her ex-boyfriend’s sister, who is considered fictive kin.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing
on 6/3/2025. She reported Youth A’s case was assigned to the
agency on 12/8/2023. She stated, at the onset of the case, the
goal was reunification with an order to pursue placement with
Sibling 1 in Texas through ICPC. Foster Care Supervisor attended
court in May of 2024 at which time Parent A’s attorney reported to
the court that Sibling 1 had become homeless. In June or July of
2024, the court changed the goal from reunification to epic
guardianship with Caregiver A. Foster Care Supervisor stated it
has been difficult to get contact information for any relatives as,
whenever she was asked, Parent A would state they didn’t have
any relatives. Parent A told Foster Care Supervisor that Sibling 2
is sick, Sibling 3 was living with Parent A until they became
homeless, Sibling 4 was in jail, and another of Youth A’s sisters
was living out of the country. Foster Care Supervisor stated she
contacted Sibling 1 who reported she was willing to take
placement of Youth A only if Youth A wanted to live with her. She
also had contact with Sibling 2 who stated she did not want Youth
A to live with her unless Youth A wanted to. Foster Care
Supervisor stated Youth A remained in contact with her siblings
throughout the case but expressed her desire to live with
Caregiver A and not her siblings. Foster Care Supervisor stated
the goal changed from reunification to epic guardianship, but
Parent A opposed the guardianship, so the goal was changed to
Another Planned Permanent Living Arrangement (APPLA.) Parent
A did not want the goal of APPLA; however, that remains the
current goal.
3

Foster Care Worker was interviewed by phone on 6/18/2025.
She stated Youth A recently provided her with a list of siblings
which included Sibling 1 who lives in Texas, Sibling 2 who was
living with Parent A and is “sick“ which Foster Care Worker
believed had something to with her organs, Sibling 3 with whom
Youth A reported having “burned bridges,” Sibling 4 who is
incarcerated, Sibling 5 who lives in Texas, Sibling 6 who in in the
Airforce and living in Italy, and Sibling 7 who lives in Ghana. Youth
A has told Foster Care Worker and the court on multiple
occasions that she does not want to live with any of her siblings.
Foster Care Worker stated the initial goal was reunification and to
pursue placement with Sibling 1; however, it was changed to
guardianship with Caregiver A, then APPLA with Caregiver A.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
Court Orders
• 11/7/23 - Youth A remain in current placement, Youth A
cannot move to Texas pending disposition in Parent A’s
criminal matter involving Youth A as the victim.
• 2/6/2024 – DHHS to file ICPC request for placement in
Texas.
• 5/22/2024 – ICPC pending with MDHHS.
• 7/16/2024 – Youth A continue in current placement who
may file for epic guardianship.
• 9/17/2024 – Goal changed to guardianship with Youth A’s
current placement.
• 12/17/2024 – Placement not addressed.
• 3/25/2025 – Goal Change to APPLA.
• 6/20/2025 – Reasonable efforts were made toward relative
placement, Permanency goal is APPLA.
5/22/24 Letter from Youth A stating she:
• does not want to leave her current school or placement.
• does not want to go to Texas until after she finishes high
school.
• wants to stay with Caregiver A until after she graduates.
Screenshot of text from Youth A to Foster Care Worker with
the following list of her siblings’ locations:
• Sibling 1 –Texas
• Sibling 2 – Flint, Sick
• Sibling 3 – Flint, specific location unknown
• Sibling 4 – Jail
4

• Sibling 5 – Texas
• Sibling 6 – Italy
• Sibling 7 – Ghana
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as Youth A has expressed her
desire to live with her current caregiver and to not live with any of
her siblings. Agency staff discussed placement with two of Youth
A’s siblings who both expressed they would only take placement
of Youth A if Youth A wanted to live with them. The permanency
goal has been either guardianship or APPLA for the past year,
negating the need to pursue relative placement. Additionally, the
court made a finding that the agency made reasonable effort
toward locating relative placement.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans
Section • (1) The initial service plan, as required in R
Description 400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following information:
• (e) A plan that has as its goal reunification of the
child with his or her family or another goal of
permanent placement. The plan shall include all the
following information:
• (i) The permanency goal for the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are concerns that reunification was not appropriately
explored.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Parent A was interviewed by phone on 5/23/2025 and 5/28/2025.
She was largely focused on what she stated is a “false case”
against her and the federal lawsuit she is pursuing against all
parties involved, which made it difficult to attain needed
information. She stated the assigned foster care agency staff have
never given her a chance, have lied, and have falsified
documents. She stated she has never been provided with any
service referrals and had to find service providers on her own. She
stated she has completed everything on her service plan, but they
keep changing the goal; reporting the goal was initially
reunification, then it was changed to guardianship, and now it has
been changed to APPLA. She later stated she initially agreed to
guardianship as the goal because Youth A’s behaviors got to be
too much for her. When asked if she had spoken to her attorney
5

about the goal changes, she stated she has fired several
attorneys and is representing herself. She reported Youth A’s
attorney is “awful” and has tried to terminate Parent A’s rights.
Parent A stated the agency has put a no contact order in place so
she can only communicate with them through email. When asked
for clarification regarding the no contact order, she stated the
agency staff have not responded to her text messages, phone
calls, or emails for months; however, this contradicted several
statements she made about her recent contact with the worker
and supervisor. She then stated she was told by agency staff
yesterday she can only communicate with them via email.
Throughout the interview, Parent A repeated agency staff have
told all of her service providers and Youth A’s school that Parent
A’s rights are terminated, so they will not provide her services or
any documentation she requests.
Program Manager was interviewed via video conferencing on
5/30/2025. She stated the goal of the case was changed from
reunification to guardianship at which point the agency staff
typically do not provide services to parents, but the judge on this
case continues to order services be provided, so the assigned
foster care worker continues to assist Parent A with services. She
stated, at one point, the court ordered all communication with
Parent A occur via email, which it does. She stated the agency
continues to work with Parent A; however, Parent A is threatening
toward agency staff and service providers, so there is currently a
plan being developed with MDHHS as to how to proceed with the
case in order to keep everyone safe. Program Manager denied
ever telling anyone Parent A’s rights have been terminated.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing
on 6/3/2025. She stated, when the agency accepted Youth A’s
case in December of 2023, the goal was reunification, and all
communication occurred through Parent A’s attorney. Foster Care
Supervisor stated the case was not adjudicated until September of
2024 at which time the goal was guardianship; however, agency
staff had been providing services to Parent A since case
acceptance. She reported Parent A was provided with housing
referrals/resources, bus passes, and parent education referral and
service. She stated Parent A has been homeless throughout most
of the case and has moved between Saginaw, Detroit, and Flint,
which the agency has provided resources and services for all
locations. Foster Care Supervisor stated Parent A also has a
criminal case for which she was ordered to complete conflict
resolution, anger management, and psychological evaluation.
6

Foster Care Supervisor reported Parent A has completed all court
ordered services.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed by phone on 6/18/2025.
Foster Care Worker stated she has provided Parent A with
referrals to the parent partner program, mental health providers,
and has provided housing and transportation
assistance/resources. She stated reunification has not been the
goal since last April. Foster Care Worker reported there was a
court hearing the same day as the interview during which Parent A
stated she does not want Youth A and called Youth A a liar.
Foster Care Worker stated all services for Parent A were
suspended during the hearing and the goal remains APPLA.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
Case Contacts
• 3/13/2024 – Email from Foster Care Supervisor to Parent A
and Parent A’s attorney with a list of service providers for
parent education, anger management, and conflict
resolution
• 11/25/2024 – Email from Foster Care Worker to Parent A
and Parent A’s attorney with list of service providers in
Detroit for parent education, anger management, and
conflict resolution as Parent A moved to a homeless shelter
in Detroit
• 1/2/2025 – Email from Foster Care Worker to Parent A with
housing resource referrals in Flint as Parent A had
relocated to that area
• 1/6/2025 – Email to Parent A from Foster Care Worker to
Parent A with anger management resources
• 2/10/2025 – Email to Parent A from Foster Care Worker
with referral to conflict resolution class
• 4/7/2025 – Phone call between Foster Care Supervisor and
Parent A during which Foster Care Worker reported to
Parent A
• 4/30/2025 – Phone call from Foster Care Worker to Parent
A to inform her of family therapy arrangement, voicemail
left
• 5/2/2025 – Phone call to Foster Care Worker from Parent
A. Foster Care Worker told Parent A she would have to
initiate intake with the family therapy office as the agency
was not allowed to do so while Parent A had parental rights
to Youth A
Court Orders
• 11/7/23 - Neither parent adjudicated.
7

• 2/6/2024 – Reasonable efforts were made toward
reunification (Parent A not adjudicated).
• 5/22/2024 – Reasonable efforts were made toward
reunification (Parent A not adjudicated) .
• 7/16/2024 – Reasonable efforts were made toward
reunification (Parent A not adjudicated).
• 9/17/2024 –Parent A adjudicated, Reasonable efforts were
made toward reunification, goal changed to guardianship.
• 12/17/2024 – Reasonable efforts made toward goal, Goal
changed to reunification, Parent A’s services suspended.
• 3/25/2025 – Reasonable efforts were made to finalize the
court ordered permanency goal, Youth A does not wish to
return to her parents’ care and due to her age,
consideration must be given to her wishes. Goal changed
to APPLA.
• 6/20/2025 – Reasonable efforts were made toward
permanency goal, Parent A no longer required to engage in
services with the agency.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as, at the time the agency
accepted case responsibility, they provided referrals to Parent A
despite her not having been adjudicated. When Parent A was
adjudicated, the permanency goal was changed to guardianship
after which the agency continued to provide services. Currently,
the goal is APPLA and Parent A no longer has to be provided with
services. Additionally, the court found that the agency provided
reasonable efforts toward the goal during every court hearing
since Parent A was adjudicated.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person
Section contact
Description • (4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there is a
court determination that contact is detrimental to either
child.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Parenting time visits have not adequately been offered.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
8

Parent A was interviewed by phone on 5/23/2025. She reported
she has only had one face to face contact with Youth A in 2 years.
She was unable to provide a clear explanation as to why this was
the case as she, at times, stated the judge ordered no contact, but
at other times during the conversation stated the agency was
refusing to facilitate parenting time or that Youth A did not want to
visit with Parent A. She stated she and Youth A were in
counseling for three weeks before the court ordered there be no
contact between them. She stated this was based on lies the
Guardian Ad Litem told the court. She stated Youth A called her
on Mother’s Day this year for the first time in 2 years. Parent A
stated the court has now ordered that parenting time and
counseling occur, but there have not yet been any parenting
times.
On 5/28/2025 Parent A called and stated her daughter was
supposed to attend counseling with her on Tuesday via Zoom, but
her daughter jumped onto the meeting then left, stating she had to
attend a graduation. Parent A stated she didn’t understand this
because Youth A is not graduating. Parent A was then asked if the
Zoom counseling was supposed to be parenting time. Parent A
responded that the judge ordered counseling in a therapeutic
setting, but parenting time was supposed to be supervised which
the agency was not making happen. Parent A then read her court
order aloud, which stated parenting time was to occur in a
therapeutic session. Parent A quickly ended the call so she could
follow up with her therapist.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing
on 6/3/2025. She reported the agency took over case
management responsibility for Youth A on 12/8/2023. She stated
she was the assigned foster care worker until April, when she
began supervising Foster Care Worker to whom the case was
reassigned. She stated, when the agency took over case
management, parenting time between Youth A and Parent A was
ordered to take place with the family’s therapist via Telehealth;
however, the court suspended parenting time at the 5/22/2024
hearing due to Parent A’s behavior during parenting time. At that
same hearing, the judge ordered no contact between Youth A and
Parent A because mom had sent threatening texts to Youth A.
Foster Care Supervisor reported visits were ordered to resume in
a therapeutic setting in March of 2025. She stated there have
been a few virtual visit attempts since; one visit was cut short due
to Youth A leaving the visit to attend a graduation event, and the
most recent visit did not take place due to Parent A not showing
up.
9

Foster Care Worker was interviewed by phone on 6/18/2025.
She stated there has been no parenting time allowed in person
since she was assigned the case in April of 2024 due to the court
having ordered no contact between Youth A and Parent A as the
result of Parent A engaging in witness tampering related to her
criminal case. Foster Care Worker stated, at the 3/25/25 hearing,
virtual visits in a therapeutic setting were ordered. Since that time,
there have been three visit attempts. Foster Care Worker stated
the therapist told her Parent A and Youth A attended the first visit,
which was “very explosive.” Youth A showed up to the second
visit, but Parent A did not. Youth A showed up in a timely manner
to the third visit, but Parent A was having difficulty with her
connection. She did eventually join, but Youth A had left after 15
minutes to attend a graduation event. Foster Care Worker stated
the therapist provided a written report to the court recommending
the family therapy and visits be suspended. Foster Care Worker
stated there was a hearing earlier in the day during which the
court ordered contact between Youth A and Parent A be at Youth
A’s discretion.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
Court Orders
• 11/7/23 - Parenting time supervised, only in therapeutic
setting by Zoom until Parent A’s hospital release.
• 2/6/2024 – Parenting time supervised in therapeutic setting
to continue with MDHHS discretion to expand to face to
face visits.
• 5/22/2024 – Parenting time suspended, family therapy
discontinued due to alleged disrupted behavior by Parent
A, No contact between Parent A and Youth A.
• 7/16/2024 – Parenting time suspended.
• 9/4/2024 – Parenting time suspended.
• 9/17/2024 – Parenting time supervised in therapeutic
setting.
• 12/17/2024 – In best interest of Youth A to suspend contact
with Parent A.
• 3/25/2025 –Parenting time supervised in a therapeutic
setting at the recommendation of the therapist.
• 6/20/2025 – Communication with Parent A is at Youth A’s
discretion.
Social Work Contacts
10

• 2/6/2024 – 5/22/2024 – During which time parenting time
was to occur in therapeutic setting
o 2/22/204 Virtual Parenting time between Youth A
and Parent A with their family therapist, reportedly
went well.
o 3/13/2024 Email from family therapist to Foster Care
Supervisor reporting Youth A and Parent A had
three sessions together and the therapist was
concerned about the effects the sessions were
having on Youth A and Parent A’s mental health.
o 4/2/2024 Virtual Parenting time between Youth A
and Parent A with their family therapist reportedly
went well.
o 4/17/2024 Virtual Parenting time between Youth A
and Parent A with their family therapist, Youth A was
40 minutes late.
o 5/8/2024 Virtual Parenting time between Youth A
and Parent A with their family therapist. Foster Care
Worker and Foster Care Supervisor were also
present. Parent A left the session midway through.
The therapist recommended that therapy be
discontinued until after court.
o 5/14/2024 Email from the family therapist to Foster
Care Supervisor stating she told Parent A on
5/9/2024 she would not be scheduling any more
sessions until after 5/22/2024 court hearing due to
concerns about the stress the sessions were
causing Youth A.
o 5/22/2024 Letter from Youth A stating she doesn’t
want face to face or video visits with Parent A.
• 9/17/2024 – 12/17/2024– During which time parenting time
was to occur in therapeutic setting
o 10/7/2024 Phone call from Parent A to Foster Care
Supervisor reporting Parent A is hospitalized in Flint.
o 10/21/2024 Foster Care Worker attempted to contact
Parent A at Flint Neurological Center; however, she
had not shown up for her appointment.
11

o 11/12/2024 Text from Parent A to Foster Care
Worker stating Parent A admitted to hospital in
Detroit.
o Multiple phone calls, text messages, and emails to
Foster Care Worker, Foster Care Supervisor,
Caregiver A, Youth A’s Attorney, and Parent A’s
Attorney, which were threatening and accusatory.
• 3/25/2025 – 6/20/2025– During which time parenting time
was to occur in therapeutic setting.
o 6/18/2025 email from the therapist providing therapy to
Youth A and Parent A to Foster Care Worker
recommending discontinuation of services based on the
following:
▪ First session was held via Telehealth. It was clear
there were communication issues. Therapist thought
best to continue with Telehealth although Parent A
thought it was unfair she had been denied face to
face meetings with Youth A.
▪ Parent A did not show up in the first 15 minutes of
the second session, so Youth A logged off.
▪ Parent A was driving at the beginning of the third
session and did not have a good internet connection.
Youth A indicated she had to get off the call at
5:15pm to attend a graduation which upset Parent A.
▪ Parent A would text the therapist making demands,
trying to control therapist’s time and therapy
sessions.
▪ Parent A was disrespectful to the therapist.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as parenting times were
provided to Parent A when allowed by court order.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
12

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
July 18, 2025
______________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 21, 2025
